headline: Four out of every 10 Nigerians live below poverty line – World bank
summarized_story:
Four out of every 10 Nigerians live below poverty line – World bankNigeria currently need long-term reforms to foster and sustain pro-poor growth and raise citizens out of poverty, World Bank report reveals.
According to the Bank’s latest report titled, ‘A Better Future for All Nigerians: Nigeria Poverty Assessment 2022’, Nigeria requires macroeconomic reforms including fiscal, trade, and exchange rate policy; policies to boost the productivity of farm and non-farm household enterprises among others.
The report, which represents the culmination of the World Bank’s engagement on poverty and inequality-relevant data and analytics in Nigeria in the past two years, brings together the latest evidence on the profile and drivers of poverty in Nigeria.
As many as 4 in 10 Nigerians live below the national poverty line,” it stated.
“Data can provide vital guidance on how to design, monitor, and evaluate pro-poor projects and programs, giving a voice to poor and vulnerable Nigerians” added Jonathan Lain, World Bank Economist and co-author of the report.

headline: Many rich Nigerians one shock away from poverty – W/Bank
summarized_story:
The World Bank has said in a new report that many rich Nigerians are only one small shock away from falling into poverty.
The multilateral lender, in its ‘Nigeria Poverty Assessment 2022’ report, said the COVID-19 crisis was driving up Nigeria’s poverty rate, pushing more than five million additional people into poverty by 2022.
“Many non-poor Nigerians are only one small shock away from falling into poverty, while those who are already poor could be pushed into even deeper deprivation,” the World Bank said.
“This problem may currently be getting worse: climate change threatens to make floods and droughts more frequent and more severe, compounding this challenge for poverty reduction in Nigeria.
“The pro-poor government spending that could broaden the base of growth is currently lacking in Nigeria,” the World Bank added.
